1	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-clinton-kerry-idUSKCN0YU1U8	Kerry says all should celebrate Clinton win
column2: regardless of party	"

column1: ABU DHABI - Hillary Clinton's victory in the Democratic presidential primary race is a ""historic moment"" for the United States and should be celebrated by Republicans and Democrats alike
column2: U.S. Secretary of State John Kerry said on Wednesday.Clinton declared herself the Democratic Party nominee on Tuesday evening after winning the New Jersey primary
column3: setting up a general election campaign against Republican candidate Donald Trump in the Nov. 8 election. She is the first woman in American history to attain the presidential nomination of a major political party.

column1: As a father of two daughters
column2: I'm proud
column3: Kerry told reporters while traveling from China to the United Arab Emirates
column4: adding that he had sent a message to Clinton congratulating her on the outcome. ""She'll make a terrific president.""    Kerry
column5: who was the Democratic nominee for president in 2004 but lost to Republican incumbent President George W. Bush
column6: said Clinton's achievement was a ""truly historic moment for the nation.""

column1: Everybody ought to celebrate it
column2: Republican or Democrat alike
column3: he said. ""It's a breakthrough
column4: and I think that whether you're voting for Trump or you're voting for her or whoever
column5: you ought to take pride.""

column1: (Reporting by Yeganeh Torbati; Editing by Alistair Bell)"
2	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-steyer-idUSKCN0YU1SM	Billionaire environmental activist Tom Steyer endorses Clinton	"

WASHINGTON Environmental activist Tom Steyer endorsed Hillary Clinton on Wednesday for U.S. president a day after she secured the Democratic nomination to run in the Nov. 8 election.""Hillary Clinton is an experienced leader who will lead us to victory because she embodies the best values of our country
column2: Steyer
column3: a former hedge fund manager
column4: said in a statement. ""Now is the time to come together to defeat Donald Trump
column5: who is utterly unfit to be our next president.""

column1: (Reporting by Doina Chiacu; Editing by Chizu Nomiyama)"
3	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-britain-trump-idUSKCN0YU1K6	'Hi Donald
column2: we're Muslims!' Scottish offer to teach Trump in visit	"

column1: By Elisabeth O'Leary
| EDINBURGH

EDINBURGH Scottish Muslims have invited Donald Trump to visit a mosque and learn about their faith during his visit to Scotland this month in the hope of changing his views.The presumptive Republican U.S. presidential candidate
column2: whose mother was Scottish
column3: last year proposed a temporary ban on Muslims entering the United States as a response to Islamist attacks in Paris and California
column4: causing a furor in Europe.Accepting a visit to learn about the Muslim community might help show that he is not so extreme
column5: Edinburgh Central Mosque Imam Yayha Barry told Reuters.""I would say: 'Hi Donald
column6: we're Muslims
column7: welcome to our mosque! Do you still see Muslims as a threat to Western civilizations?'"" he said.Trump's views prompted widespread opposition in Britain
column8: where he owns two golf courses on the west and east Scottish coasts. His comments about stopping Mexican migrants entering the United States also caused offense
column9: leading to the withdrawal of Scottish business and academic accolades. Prime Minister David Cameron said the remarks by the potential leader of Britain's closest international ally were ""divisive

column1: Neither Cameron nor Scotland's First Minister Nicola Sturgeon plan to meet him on his visit
column2: which coincides with the result of Britain's referendum on EU membership on June 24. Spiritual leaders in the Islamic community invited Trump to ""learn more about the Muslims that he offends"".""We would welcome the opportunity to show him the work that we are doing in the community in Edinburgh when he comes to Scotland
column3: said Hafiz Ghafoor of Annandale Mosque and Munawar Hussain
column4: secretary of Roxburgh St Mosque and Islamic Centre
column5: in a joint statement.

column1: Trump's relationship with Scotland has been rocky since he contested a decision to build an offshore wind farm opposite his golf course in Aberdeenshire. His trip will include a visit there as well as to his courses at Turnberry
column2: in southwestern Scotland
column3: and Doonbeg
column4: in Ireland.Protests at Trump's ""misogynist
column5: racist and xenophobic"" views are planned by Aberdeen University students during his visit
column6: the president of the Students' Association said. A spokesperson for the Trump Organisation did not respond to a request to comment.

column1: Scottish Liberal Democrat leader Willie Rennie said Trump should witness first hand the work being done by local Muslims to reach across faiths and help those in need.""Muslims are our friends
column2: colleagues
column3: family and neighbors. When he insults them in such a grotesque manner he insults us all.""About 77
column4: 000 Scots are Muslims
column5: or 1.4 percent of the population
column6: according to the latest official census in 2011. (Reporting By Elisabeth O'Leary

column1: 4	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-sanders-idUSKCN0YU10R	Sanders plants seeds for a lasting U.S. progressive movement	"
By John Whitesides
| WASHINGTON
WASHINGTON Bernie Sanders' upstart U.S. presidential campaign may be headed to defeat
column2: but his goals of reining in Wall Street
column3: ending big money in politics and eradicating income inequality were the big winners in the bruising Democratic race.Sanders
column4: who started as a little-known long-shot
column5: pushed the party and established front-runner Hillary Clinton sharply to the left during a long primary battle. Along the way
column6: the 74-year-old U.S. senator from Vermont energized young and progressive voters and prepared the ground for what his allies predict will be a lasting influence on the party.Clinton
column7: one of the best-known political figures in the United States
column8: clinched the Democratic Party's nomination in a last round of state nominating contests on Tuesday.  But even before her victory
column9: Sanders began taking steps to turn his newfound political influence into an enduring progressive movement.In the last few weeks
column10: he has lent his influence and fundraising power to progressive congressional and state legislative candidates who share his agenda
column11: urging his supporters around the country to donate to their campaigns.Sanders also appointed prominent activists to the panel writing the issues platform for the party's convention in July
column12: ensuring a strong voice in the process.His convention delegates will push for changes to party primary rules
column13: including letting independents vote in primaries and reducing the influence of superdelegates
column14: the hundreds of party elites who can support any candidate regardless of voting in their constituencies
column15: and who in this primary season have largely backed Clinton.""I do think we are going to see real changes in the Democratic Party going forward because of Bernie. The future of the party is with the people supporting Sanders
column17: executive director of Democracy for America
column18: a liberal Vermont-based group that rose from Howard Dean's failed 2004 presidential bid and endorsed Sanders this time.""He has proven the power of this message

column1: During the campaign
column2: Sanders forced Clinton to tack left repeatedly on issues ranging from her support for a higher minimum wage to her opposition to the Asian trade pact and Keystone XL oil pipeline.Sanders' progressive allies said those shifts by Clinton will be helpful in the Nov. 8 election against presumptive Republican nominee Donald Trump
column3: who has touted an anti-trade and pro-jobs economic agenda
column4: and for Democrats in their efforts to recapture a majority in the U.S. Senate.""When the story of the 2016 election is told
column5: a major part of it will be that Bernie Sanders helped the Democratic Party turn up the volume on economic populism issues
column6: said Adam Green
column7: co-founder of the liberal Progressive Change Campaign Committee.'FIGHT THE GOOD FIGHTS'

column1: If Democrats win back the Senate in the November election
column2: Sanders will be in line for either the chairmanship of the Budget Committee or the Health
column3: Education
column4: Labor and Pensions committee
column5: both powerful platforms to advance his ideas.Chamberlain said Sanders would create a formidable one-two  punch in the Senate with Elizabeth Warren
column6: a Massachusetts senator who has been the leader of the party's progressive wing.""Bernie Sanders is going to fight all the good fights
column7: he said. ""With Bernie Sanders and Elizabeth Warren we're going to see a Senate team that will be very powerful.""Sanders' investment in the next generation of progressive politicians
column9: is aimed at spawning a new generation of liberals who back his agenda.

column1: He has sent emails to his grassroots fundraising list urging his donors to back six insurgent congressional candidates and eight statehouse candidates who echo his economic message
column2: sparking a flood of donations to their campaigns. More endorsements are expected.""Our movement is so powerful that we can change congressional elections overnight. Let's keep going
column3: Sanders said on Tuesday in an email to supporters asking them to support two more candidates for Congress - Eric Kingson in New York and Paul Clements in Michigan.Justin Bamberg
column4: a first-term state representative from South Carolina
column5: said he received about $70
column6: 000 in small-dollar donations after Sanders sent an email to his supporters backing Bamberg. In Bamberg's first campaign
column9: he said.""They don't know me from Adam
column10: but they believe in Senator Sanders
column11: and because of that they believe in the people that Senator Sanders has supported
column13: adding he was also getting calls offering to volunteer on his behalf.Terry Alexander
column14: a South Carolina state representative backed by Sanders
column15: said he also had received about $70
column16: 000 in donations after the Sanders email. The money freed him from worrying about raising funds
column17: giving him more time to focus on meeting voters
column18: he said.""It has made a difference in how people see my candidacy
column19: it's created a lot of enthusiasm and a tremendous boost in fundraising

column1: 5	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-california-senate-idUSKCN0YT16J	California poised to shut out Republicans from U.S. Senate race	"
By Sharon Bernstein
| SACRAMENTO
column2: Calif.

column1: SACRAMENTO
column2: Calif. California voters on Tuesday were poised to choose two Democrats to face off against each other in the race to succeed Barbara Boxer in the U.S. Senate
column3: shutting out Republicans in a sign of diminished support in America's most populous state.State Attorney General Kamala Harris and U.S. Representative Loretta Sanchez will meet in what would be the state's first single-party Senate election under a 2010 California law advancing the top two primary vote-getters to the general election
column4: regardless of party affiliation.With 16 percent of precincts reporting in early returns on Tuesday
column5: Harris
column7: led the crowded field of 34 candidates with 40 percent of the vote. None of the Republican contenders came close to Sanchez
column9: who was firmly in second place with 16  percent of the vote.Boxer
column12: is retiring after 24 years in the Senate.Republicans hold no statewide offices in California and represent about 27 percent of registered voters. The state
column13: home to former Republican Presidents Richard Nixon and Ronald Reagan
column14: last elected a Republican to the U.S. Senate in 1988.On Tuesday
column15: former California Republican Party chairman Duf Sundheim was in third place with 10 percent in early returns
column16: followed by fellow Republican Phil Wyman with 6 percent.      Harris is the daughter of two college professors. Of African-American and Indian descent
column17: she was raised amid civil rights activism in Berkeley and Oakland
column18: eventually becoming a prosecutor in San Francisco. She was elected attorney general in 2010 and 2014.

column1: For the primary
column2: Harris ran a tightly controlled campaign
column3: touting her role negotiating a settlement with big banks over the mortgage meltdown and using her position as the state's top prosecutor to fight human trafficking
column4: cyber crime and other issues.Sanchez
column5: who represents Orange County near Los Angeles
column6: has served in Congress since 1997. Her win in the once staunchly Republican county was an early sign of California's demographic shift
column7: as the state became more ethnically diverse and far more Democratic.

column1: COULD GO NEGATIVE
Such a matchup could easily go negative
column2: experts said
column3: straining relationships within a party that are already bruised by the tense competition between former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton and U.S. Senator Bernie Sanders for the Democratic presidential nomination for the Nov. 8 election. Clinton and Sanders also face off in California on Tuesday.""The fact that they're both in the same party doesn't mean they're going to treat each other with kid gloves
column4: political analyst Sherry Bebitch Jeffe said of Harris and Sanchez.""When ideological and policy differences aren't as great
column5: it's only natural for the candidates to focus on personal issues
column6: said Dan Schnur
column7: who heads the Unruh Institute of Politics at the University of Southern California.

column1: Sanchez
column2: seeking to become the state's first Latina U.S. senator
column3: has raised less money than Harris and trails her by about 8 percentage points in polls. But factors including a recent surge in voter registration among Latinos will make her a strong competitor in the general election
column4: analysts said.She has positioned herself more to the political center than her opponent.With support from Latinos
column5: independents and Republicans
column6: Sanchez could win in November despite Harris' advantages
column7: Schnur said.""We're prepared for any turn in the race
column8: said Harris spokesman Nathan Click. A Sanchez campaign spokesman did not respond to a request for comment. (Reporting by Sharon Bernstein; Editing by Peter Cooney and Michael Perry)"

column2: to meet with Sanders: White House	"

column1: WASHINGTON President Barack Obama called former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton on Tuesday to congratulate her on securing the delegates needed to become the Democratic presidential nominee
column2: the White House said.""Her historic campaign inspired millions and is an extension of her lifelong fight for middle-class families and children
column3: White House spokesman Josh Earnest said in a statement.Obama also spoke to Democratic presidential candidate Bernie Sanders
column4: a U.S. senator from Vermont
column5: and will meet with him on Thursday at Sanders' request
column6: Earnest said.

column1: The president thanked Senator Sanders for energizing millions of Americans with his commitment to issues like fighting economic inequality and special interests' influence on our politics
column2: Earnest said.

7	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-ryan-idUSKCN0YT0AM	Under fire from Republicans
column2: Trump says he'll stop talking about judge	"

column1: By Richard Cowan and Steve Holland
| WASHINGTON
WASHINGTON Bowing to pressure from fellow Republicans
column2: Donald Trump said on Tuesday he would no longer talk about a Mexican-American judge after U.S. House Speaker Paul Ryan denounced the presidential candidate's criticism of the jurist as textbook racism.But Trump refused entreaties from party leaders to disavow his charge that U.S. District Judge Gonzalo Curiel was showing bias because of his Mexican heritage and should recuse himself from a lawsuit alleging fraud at Trump's defunct Trump University real estate training school.Trump said in a statement that his previous remarks about Curiel had been misconstrued.""I do not feel that one's heritage makes them incapable of being impartial
column3: but
column4: based on the rulings that I have received in the Trump University civil case
column5: I feel justified in questioning whether I am receiving a fair trial
column6: the presumptive Republican nominee said. Trump added that he did not plan to comment further on the matter.Trump had been suggesting that Curiel's heritage was influencing the judge's opinion about the case because of Trump's campaign rhetoric about illegal immigration. Trump has pledged to seal the U.S.-Mexico border with a wall
column7: and has said Mexico is sending rapists and drug dealers to the United States.Ryan
column10: which have threatened to disrupt Republicans' already rocky efforts to unite behind the candidate.""I regret those comments that he made. Claiming a person can't do their job because of their race is sort of like the textbook definition of a racist comment. I think that should be absolutely disavowed
column11: Ryan told reporters.The controversy over Trump's attacks on the judge has set back his efforts to try to unify the Republican party behind him ahead of the Nov. 8 general election when he will face off against presumptive Democratic nominee Hillary Clinton.Speaking to supporters at the golf club he owns in the hilly suburbs of New York later on Tuesday
column12: Trump laid out his vision for the meaning of his campaign slogan ""America First
column13: talking about its implications for trade
column15: financial regulation and tax policies.Breaking with his usual practice of speaking off the cuff
column16: Trump read from a teleprompter and left without taking questions from reporters.

column1: Ryan
column2: who endorsed Trump last week after initial misgivings
column3: said he still supported his candidacy
column4: saying Trump would be preferable to Clinton.Behind the scenes
column5: Trump has been pressured from friends and family to back down
column6: fearful of the damage that may be done to his prospects in the general election
column7: a source close to the Trump campaign said.New Jersey Governor Chris Christie
column8: a potential Trump vice presidential running mate
column9: was spotted at Trump Tower in New York before Trump's statement was issued. Christie earlier in the day defended Trump as ""not a racist.""""Some of his friends and family have talked to him and asked him to drop it and so far he won't do it
column11: speaking before Trump's statement was issued. ""Everybody is mystified about why he would keep doing it.""HIGH ANXIETY

column1: Ryan's emphatic rejection of Trump's comments showed anxiety among party leaders about their ability to hang on to control of the U.S. Congress in November if voters trounce Trump and also punish candidates for other offices on the Republican ticket.Ryan's counterpart in the Senate
column2: Mitch McConnell
column3: said Trump should stop attacking minority groups.""My advice to our nominee is to start talking about the issues that the American people care about
column4: and to start doing it now
column5: the Senate Republican leader told reporters.""In addition to that
column6: it's time to quit attacking various people that you competed with or various minority groups in the country and get on message.""Senator Mark Kirk
column7: an Illinois Republican who said back in March he would support whoever turned out to be the Republican nominee
column8: said on Tuesday he could not support Trump because he did not have the ""temperament necessary"" for the White House.

column1: Kirk condemned Trump's comments on Curiel as ""dead wrong"" and ""un-American."" Kirk is seeking re-election in November.During the Republican primary campaigns
column2: in which Trump vanquished 16 opponents with a stream of insults to rivals and inflammatory comments about Muslims
column3: immigrants and women
column4: establishment Republicans squirmed over the prospect of the former reality television host becoming their standard-bearer.But many
column5: seeing no alternative
column6: have reconciled themselves to a Trump run for the White House.'UNFAIR POSITION'

column1: Trump's continuing practice of making explosive remarks about racial
column2: religious and gender issues is making Republicans
column3: including those who have embraced him
column4: uncomfortable.With greater scrutiny of Trump now that he is set to formally win the Republican presidential nomination at the party's July convention in Cleveland
column5: there are concerns about the party's ability to maintain control of the House of Representatives and Senate.""Trump's continuing missteps
column6: punctuated by his outrageous and indefensible comments about Judge Curiel
column7: make that goal much more difficult to achieve
column9: a senior adviser to former presidential candidate Marco Rubio and a senior fellow at the conservative Hoover Institution. (Reporting by Richard Cowan and Steve Holland; Additional reporting by David Morgan
column10: Susan Heavey and Doina Chiacu; Editing by Frances Kerry and Howard Goller)"

column1: 8	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-trump-filing-idUSKCN0YU000	Trump lawyers channel Obama in court filing	"
By Karen Freifeld
| NEW YORK
NEW YORK When lawyers for Donald Trump asked a court to throw out one of the proposed class actions over Trump University
column2: they backed it up with a financial disclosure meant to bolster the Republican presidential candidate's credentials as a global businessman.But the form they filed with the court was actually that of the man Trump hopes to succeed in the White House
column3: Democratic President Barack Obama.The president's nine-page disclosure filed before his 2012 re-election was erroneously included as an exhibit to a motion Trump filed in April asking U.S. District Judge Gonzalo Curiel for the Southern District of California to toss the case before trial
column4: according to a person familiar with the case. A corrected exhibit was filed on Tuesday. Plaintiffs' lawyer Jason Forge seized on the goof in a court document filed late on Friday opposing Trump's motion. Forge said the candidate's filing was meant for a court in ""Bizarro world.""

column1: This is just one example of Trump's statement's complete lack of credibility
column2: Forge said.Julie Fei
column3: a spokeswoman for O'Melveny & Myers
column4: the firm that has been representing Trump in the case
column5: declined to comment.In court filings
column6: Trump's lawyers said the form supported the ""undisputed fact"" that Trump is chairman
column7: president and chief executive of the Trump Organization
column8: which conducts business around the world and is affiliated with over 500 companies.

column1: Instead
column2: it showed Obama's royalties from his memoir ""Dreams from My Father"" and disclosed the first family's 2011 assets of between $2.6 million and $8.3 million.Trump is facing two lawsuits in California and one in New York over Trump University that allege the series of real estate seminars taught students nothing and defrauded them of as much as $35
column3: 000 each in fees.

column1: The presumptive Republican nominee for the Nov. 8 election has raised the litigation on the campaign trail
column2: calling the lawsuits baseless and politically motivated
column3: and accusing the Indiana-born Curiel of being biased against him because of his Mexican ancestry. Trump's lawyers intended to file the 92-page financial disclosure form he made public last summer at the time he announced he was running for president. That lists some $1.4 billion in assets
column4: including real estate and other holdings
column5: and $265 million in liabilities. The disclosure does not note his net worth
column6: which he has said is over $10 billion. (Reporting by Karen Freifeld; Editing by Anthony Lin and Peter Cooney)"

column1: 9	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-gm-idUSKCN0YT2V4	Trump criticizes GM for Mexico investments	"
By David Shepardson
Republican presidential candidate Donald Trump rebuked General Motors Co (GM.N) on Tuesday
column2: widening his criticism of American companies that have invested in Mexico.Trump has made criticism of Ford Motor Co (F.N) a staple of his campaign speeches for more than a year
column3: repeatedly suggesting that the Dearborn
column4: Michigan
column5: automaker would back down from plans to expand in Mexico or face a 35 percent tariff on vehicle exports.Trump also has criticized Carrier
column6: a manufacturer of air conditioning units
column7: which is owned by United Technologies Corp and Mondelez International Inc (MDLZ.O)
column9: for shifting jobs to Mexico.""I am fighting hard to bring jobs back to the United States. Many companies - like Ford
column12: Carrier - are moving production to Mexico. Drugs and illegal immigrants are also pouring across our border. This is bad for all Americans
column14: Trump said in a statement defending his comments about a Mexican-American judge overseeing civil lawsuits against Trump University. His view of an ethnically biased judiciary has drawn criticism
column15: including from within his own party. A spokeswoman for Trump did not immediately respond to a request for comment on why Trump had decided to criticize GM.

column1: GM spokesman Jim Cain declined comment on Trump's criticism.In December 2014
column2: GM said it was investing $5 billion in Mexico through 2018 - a move that would allow it to double its production capacity at its plants around the country. GM said in 2014 the investment would create 5
column3: 600 jobs in Mexico.

column1: The Detroit News reported in May that GM plans next year to move some light-duty pickup production to the Flint Assembly Plant from Mexico
column2: according to a memo from UAW Local 598 to membership.Mexican auto production has been rising in recent years as numerous automakers expand operations.Mexico produced 3.4 million vehicles in 2015
column3: the seventh largest vehicle producer worldwide
column4: and could surpass South Korea by 2020
column5: producing more than 5 million vehicles
column6: according to industry forecasts.

column1: Ford has repeatedly rejected Trump's criticism and emphasized its significant U.S. investments and employment.In April
column2: Ford announced it would invest $1.6 billion to build more small cars in Mexico. In 2015
column3: Ford said it would invest $2.5 billion in new engine and transmission plants in Mexico
column4: creating 3
column5: 800 jobs. (Reporting by David Shepardson; Editing by Howard Goller)"
